title: 90s pop star battling to save life of daughter, 4, with inoperable brain tumour
text:
Christina, 4, is battling an inoperable brain tumour (Picture: Kenny Thomas) Much like any parent would, Kenny Thomas thought his daughter’s tiredness was down to the new nursery she had started rather than anything more sinister. 
The soul singer, who had four hit UK singles in the 1990s, had not long moved with his family to Norfolk to start a new life somewhere more idyllic than the bustle of London.
Theresa May will not trigger Article 50 until the end of March But shortly after four-year-old Christina began to feel fatigued, she started to develop a persistent limp that grew so bad that one day she asked to be picked up and carried to school.
It was growing to appear much worse than the trampolining injury her father hoped it might be, however, frustratingly blood tests and then an x-ray all came back negative.
Determined to seek answers, Kenny and his wife, Francisa, were referred to a neurologist, but had not yet had an appointment when their daughter’s condition deteriorated so rapidly they were forced to turn to A & E for urgent attention.
The family had not long moved to Norfolk for a new life when Christina fell ill (Picture: Kenny Thomas) Eventually, an MRI scan in February would give the family answers, although, as Kenny could tell from doctors’ faces, it was not good news.
Christina had a mid-brain giloma that was inoperable, whatsmore specialists believe it has all the characteristics of an aggressive cancerous tumour.
Desperate hunt for man kicked, punched and forced into car in London ‘A mother’s intuition is greater than a father’s in some ways, she knew something was wrong long before me,’ he told metro.co.uk .
‘I was more dismissive. I was the one saying she hurt herself trampolining or she could have run around all day and hurt herself
‘But, truthfully, if we found out two months before we would still be in the same position with the same tumour in the same position, that you can’t operate on
They are fundraising to pay for alternative treatments to help the four-year-old (Picture: Kenny Thomas) ‘I wouldn’t wish it on my worst enemies, I really wouldn’t.’
The family were told that chemotherapy and radiotherapy would prolong Christina’s life but not save her, so concerned about the damaging side effects they have been seeking alternative treatments.
Crowdfunder set up to help farmer cleared of shooting 'thief' pay £30,000 legal costs She has been taking supplements such as Poly-MVA, and Kenny has also been speaking to specialists in America and Israel about what they can do.
Meanwhile, friends have started fundraising to help support him and have so far gathered more than £40,000 towards an £80,000 target including donations from supporters in the industry such as actor Shane Richie.
‘The people that follow me in the soul world they’ve responded amazingly and it’s going to be a real help to at least replenish what we are doing already,’ he said.
Christina first fell ill last October (Picture: Kenny Thomas) ‘Apart from the complete and utter devastation, the upside has been the response from other people, celebs and other people in the music game, it has just been amazing
‘We are doing all the things available to us here because it negates the travel and the stress but if that shows no promise then we’ll switch to plan B.’
Workers sift through 150 tonnes of rubbish to get girl's iPad back At the same time Christina was showing the first symptoms of her illness, her little brother Jude was born and now is 11 weeks old.
The couple have four children Angela, 6, Christina, Joseph, 3 and Jude.
Kenny said Christina’s condition is not deteriorating as quickly as the hospital feared it might do and they are doing all they can for her.

‘She’s got a good colour, is eating well not losing weight,’ he added.
‘Shes has moments when she’s tired but, in all honesty, kids are amazing. They are not like adults, they might be fully aware of whats going but they adapt.
‘She cant use her right hand so she has learnt to use her left hand. They are amazing little people. They just get on with it.
‘We are taking it a day at a time and doing all we can.’
To support Kenny or keep up to date on Christina’s progress visit her Just Giving page.
